Review Title: Historic Place - too little to experience
Review Text: Housed in a beautiful colonial building, the library can be visited only in the afternoons between 4 and 6 pm. You are allowed to walk through the ground floor corridors and the India room, containing books donated by India as part of the library restoration. And that's about it. Shoes not permitted to wear inside the library.
Really if you walk past and have time because it is not unforgettable. Really quite disappointed in the end. U

An iconic symbol of Srilanka historic northern province Ancient literature and documents from renowned scholars and other professionals were preserved at the Jaffna Library, and served as a cherished depository for information on the history and culture of the northern peninsula.
Worth visiting for the history due to the terrible events that burnt this place down. You can only visit the central areas but you get the overall impression. The outside and grounds are very nice.
A visit to the Jaffna library is definitely recommended. Firstly us it a nice building inside are the rooms with books and the archive. Very nice to have seen.

We wanted to take a look inside but it was Monday and the library was closed. We confined ourselves to the outside. A beautiful white building, one of the first buildings to be rebuilt after the Civil War, to symbolize the cultural revival of the city.

Review Title: Beautiful building outside with stunning gardens
Review Text: Beautiful building from outside and gardens. You have to remove your shoes before entering. Limited access inside. Reserved for members. You can roam around certain areas and can see the stacks lof books. The outside is much more interesting.

Like a phoenix risen from its ashes, this library is almost back to its old glory, and is recovering from the harrowing incident in 1981. Parking is available, and common visitors are allowed to read newspapers in the periodical section. Only members are allowed to roam the halls of bookshelves, like most libraries. Photos and videography isn't allowed
A place of historical significance. Although a lot has changed inside. It is sad to have heard the extent of loss the building has endured in the past.

The Jaffna Public Library is a cultural gem nestled in the heart of the historic city of Jaffna. Founded in 1933, this grand building is a testament to the city's love of knowledge and learning. With its stately columns, intricate carvings, and beautiful arched windows, the Jaffna Public Library is a true architectural marvel.
Beautiful piece of architecture. Great to see it being restored. However no photography allowed inside.
Not open to visitors because of COVID. Impressive from the outside but in a very busy area.  Scooter training school and test centere nearby worth spending time watching.

It was always a dream to visit this place, as it was a very important landmark of the country's civil war. It was supposed to be one of the largest libraries in Asia. Great to see it built back again to its old glory

The burning of the Jaffna Public Library (Tamil: யாழ் பொது நூலகம் எரிப்பு, Yāḻ potu nūlakam erippu Sinhala: යාපනය මහජන පුස්තකාලය ගිනිබත් කිරීම, Yāpanaya mahajana pustakālaya ginibat kirīma) took place on the night of June 1, 1981, when an organized mob of Sinhalese individuals went on a rampage, burning the library.[1] It was one of the most violent examples of ethnic biblioclasm of the 20th century.[Term][3] At the time of its destruction, the library was one of the biggest in Asia, containing over 97,000 books and manuscripts. =wikipedia =
The Library does have a historic value for sure, but I don’t consider it a must-see venue, especially if you’re having a tight schedule.
This public library was a gift from India in the 1950s. Damaged in the civil war it had now been restored and is open for business again

Beautiful architecture and one of the largest library in Asia Before it was destroyed in 1981.The library was burned in June 1981 by an organised mob of Sinhalese before the civil war. It was re-built now and it  is historic and symbolic importance to many people in Jaffna.  Visitors must remove their footwear before entering the library and  no need to pay entrance fee. We couldn't see the written old dried palm leaves stored in special sandalwood boxes??
We could only view it from the outside. A landmark of the city, its facade, history and layout are striking!
This famous library was damaged during the Civil war now fully restored The collection of books less than what was before.

There was nothing to see no info, and a waste of time unless you want to simply celebrate the reconstruction after destruction. Was asked to remove our footwear for no obvious reason since a bunch of Asian visitors came thru fully shod! Speaking inTamil I leaned they had come through the back entrance. We went thither and duly walked thru in 5 mins , passing several no entrance signs. On exiting the same individual who seemed preoccupied with footwear commented on our non compliance! Being totally disappointed suggested he actually helps visitors discover what there is to see than running the footwear police.

Public library is important visiting point for Tamils.  Library was burnt down in the racial riots and rebuilt recently. During the fire,  books & manuscripts which were lost cannot be replaced. Worth a visit for tourists whoever learnt/knew the racial hatred between Tamils and Singhalese.  It was built in a location where other touristy areas such as Jaffna fort, Pannai beach etc. Very closer to the Jaffna Town. One can walk to the library.
Alas, this public library is only open to the public, from 4.30pm to 6pm. The original building and contents was burnt to the ground by the Sri Lankan army during the civil war.

This is a pleasant building in the middle of Jaffna.  Visitors can have a look in the building, but are restricted from going into any of the actual rooms storing the books. Highlight is the facade and garden.  I wouldn’t make a special trip to Jaffna for this site, but if you have time it’s worth wandering to.
Unfortunately the library was closed when we visited. It was once the largest collection of books around 97,000. It’s a beautiful building from the outside.

Seventeen of us travelling as a group stopped over at Jaffna Public Library, along with our guide, in the evening of 6th July 2019. In front of the entrance of this elegant, spacious architectural building is the statue of Saraswati, the goddess of education, music and art. Situated in the middle of a lush well-maintained garden, the library is one of the most important landmarks in Jaffna. There were many students and others who had come here to use its facilities.  The level of maintenance and the degree of attention to library users displayed the dedication of the authorities and the staff. Unfortunately, the library is closed to visitors after the vicious attacks on churches and hotels carried out by Islamic extremists on 21st April 2019.  Only the members of the library are permitted entry.  We were permitted only to walk outside the building. I felt saddened to learn that it had been completely burnt down together with its priceless collection of books, palm-leaf manuscripts and historic documents during the civil war in June 1981.  The present library had been extensively and completely renovated and reopened to the public in 2003.  They are justified in closing it to the public to avoid a recurrence of those sad events.

We are a family of 4 of 3 generations from Colombo & Sydney but were not allowed to enter the Library premises . The lonely security guard said that he has been given instructions by the Municipality despite the public notice at the entrance which states that visitors are allowed from 3.30 to 5 pm. So much for the country's wisdom to attract travellers despite the hard times.
Situated near Jaffna fort re built recently as it was distroyed by fire about 40 years ago. Lot of the very old books were distroyed.

We visited Jaffna Public library in our tour program. It's one of the biggest library in Sri Lanka,  has good collection of books in English. Building has beautiful architecture,  area around is green and nice.
A place that you feel more happy when you see the library entrance and get to know more about everything about srilanka
We popped in because it was open and free!  It's a victorian era public library with reading rooms etc.  Frankly it wouldn't be a tourist attraction in many other cities but Jaffna doesn't have many.

Lovely traditional old library, brought back lots of childhood memories. There’s a lending station, a reading room and. children’s library to the rear. There’s nothing unduly special about it but it has great atmosphere and tradition. Public visiting is from 4:30 to 6:00 pm and it’s worth a stop if you’re passing.

Pay heed to the visiting hours! Think during the day visitors are kept out as school kids are given access. The exterior was gorgeous, with a statue of Saraswathy, the goddess of knowledge outside, set in a beautiful garden full of flowers. Read the history behind this place- very interesting.

First time I visited, I was able to go to the top floor and view the sun  set in an evening. It was not possible this time during my visit as the stairway to the top floor was closed, may be due to some construction work.
Worth a visit to this place. Sad that it was burnt down in during past civil unrest. Can combine this with a visit to the fort. Visitors cant enter the main library.
Couldn’t get very excited about this place. No doubt it’s a good place to study but for a tourist it is hot, not air conditioned and rather dull. The building however is quite impressive.
This is a beautiful architectural building. There is a statue of learning in front.Visiting hours are restricted. The garden is beautiful. A good photo opportunity.

Short experience as most of the library rooms are off limits for visitors. It's a shame to have had this place destroyed earlier, you can feel the enormous wealth of knowledge and history this place would have stored. Friendly staff and worth a short visit

If TripAdvisor allowed to give no stars at all this is the place for which I have used it. A complete waste of time. They do not allow you to enter any of the rooms which houses the books.not even to know what kind of books they have. You are only allowed to have a walk through the building. I was really excited to see this place as in terms of books they have this is legendary in Sri Lanka. So when we first went it wasn’t time for visitors which is from 4 p.m. to 6 p.m. So we came again at 4 because I wanted to see this place so much only to know that you are only allowed to appreciate the walls. If it is about a security reason you can keep a place guard to check at the ent of the tour. If you are not allowed to look at books what’s the point of permitting a visit. Never ever going to this place in my life.
This is a beautiful white building near the Jaffna fort. Known to be the biggest library in Asia in past. destroyed in 1980/1 due to the civil war. Visitors are not allowed to use books though.

The biggest library in Sri Lanka surrounded by a beautiful garden is located very close to the Jaffna clock tower, the tall white column and the police station on the way to Jaffna Fort. The library looks like a newly renovated building.
one of the most popular library in Asia. Consider World well known library. Must visit in Sri Lanka. Full of knowledge

Worth a visit to see something of local culture at play. No women in periodical reading room, tourists not allowed anywhere Toilet floors swimming in water abd no taps working 4 security men at entrance Did look nice if allowed in

Nice building, well renovated but poor content: you can just walk into a few corridors and cannot enter departments: you will not see much not see many explanations. But important historical place in Jaffna.
open from 9am to 17hrs.Entrance is free of charge.we find the all the books.there are two areas.Indian and sri lankan section.photographs not allowed inside the library

This is one of Jaffna‘s most prominent landmarks. The library was built in 1933 and got destroyed in 1981 during the civil war. This was known to be one of the largest libraries in Asia back in 1980's that had around 100,000 books and other relevant material. After the destruction that took place in the 80's, it was renovated in 2001 and today, it is the second main public library in the island.
It was funtastic experience visiting the library, saw how the micro film reader works, yazh, india corner...must visit place .very quite and people are getting benefitted...

We visited this place since we had time to kill. Did not undertake a tour of the premises but spent the time reading. They have the entire range of local newspapers to read. Also magazines. They are open to public for reading only from 4.30 to 6.30 p.m. This could have been for a longer duration or the whole day. The library is located in a beautiful campus.
Unfriendly staff. Limited rooms for tourists to visit. Not very public at all. Not worth going inside.

Jaffna public Library is Sri Lanka's prominent and biggest library. Before the war there were many books and once it was south asia's biggest library as well. Public can visit inside. Photos and videos not allowed. Two stories building. must visit place in Jaffna
this a public library and visitors only can visit 04.30 pm - 06.30 pm Mondays library is closed and please avoid on Mondays
I was not allowed inside as it was a holiday that day. But from he outside i can make out that it must be a nice place inside too.
Just went there for taking photos and couldn't visit inside. It is a nice building and must visit if you travel to Jaffna.
Mostly famous within Sri Lanka. The place could be easily visited along with the other attractions in Jaffna.

We were unable to enter the building, because foreigners may visit only from 4.30pm. But it was a joy to behold from the gate, surrounded, as it is, by beautiful trees and gardens. And of course, in a sense it is a symbol of peace.
This place is a must for all those wishing to learn war about the origin and history of the ethnic conflict.
Re-built in 2002, this is a wonderful white building housing the new library whose books were destroyed

We tried to visit when we first arrived in Jaffna but discovered it doesn't open to foreign visitors until 4:30pm. We came back a couple of days later and when we went inside discovered that we could only walk through the hallways - all the actual rooms in the library are off limits to foreigners. You can't take photos, there are no information signs or guides - there really isn't much to do. It's a shame as this library plays a big part in Sri Lanka's history and could be a really interesting attraction - perhaps it is still a little early after the war.
Non locals discouraged from entering but I suppose there is a couple of casual photo snaps of you are wandering past. Could be so much better.
It's really a most wonderful place in Jaffana (Srilanka). One of the famous library in the world. Very rare and vaulable book you can read here.

All the sections are closed to visitors, so you can only admire the building facade, walk the corridors and see closed doors What is interesting is the statue of Goddess Saraswati - the Hindu Goddess of learning at the front Avoidable
It only has historical legacy nothing much to see in present days. Make a visit in your half day city tours in Jaffna city. Can cover this max in 30 min upon arrival to library

First we came on a wrong day, then on a right day it was at a wrong hour. Then we came at 15:30 and it turned out that it opens at 16:00. Anyway, we waited and went in. Most of the halls were off-limits and could not be entered by us. There was hardly anything else to see except some corridors and insight into halls, and, of course, some pictures from the terrible fire during war times. I feel sorry to give such a poor remark and I feel sorry for what has happened to this building in the past. But if they responsible people from now want that this building is admired by the general public, they should also open it (more) to the public.

I visited this library after a long time and it is good to see it is functional again. Not sure the quality of the books though. Please not, you need to remove your foot wear before you enter the building.
Did not get to visit inside since the break time is between 1 to 4 which was a travesty because we went at 330
You are welcome to call in and look but there are rooms where you cannot enter. One of the better public buildings of Jaffna but not sure why we visited!!
Was a break in Jaffna and the library is close to where we stay. It’s an historical structure with lord Saraswathy ( god of knowledge in Hinduism) at the main entrance . worth to see when in Jaffna

The Jaffna library lacks the staff to give guided tours or have handouts regarding it's importance. This is one of the best libraries in the country & none of the local authorities are interested in developing it A visitor is only allowed to view the passages & the reception area.

The Jaffna library built in 1933 was burnt in 1981 and is a horrific reminder of the ethnic tension of the 80s. Over 97000 valuable manuscripts were destroyed (Seneviratne, 2006). It has now risen to being a new, vibrant library with areas for children, youth and is an interesting place. It is a must visit site for all locals to be reminded of the horrors of ethnic biblioclasm and to be challenged to think "Never Again" shall such a thing happen in Sri Lanka.

One of the standout buildings in Jaffna with a sad history.  Unfortunately visitors only have access to the main corridors of the building.  So fifteen minutes will do it.  If you are staying longer than a few days it may be worth joining as apparently the wifi is excellent. The children's park across the road is quiet and cool to stop for a rest.

Photographs in the library show the destruction it suffered during the civil war and it is remarkable that it has been restored Externally the impressive colonial architecture provides Jaffna with a remarkable landmark Internally not quite so impressive with many of the rooms off limits to casual visitors However, the atmosphere harks back to libraries of yesteryear with long shelves lined with books and a reverential hush reinforced by prominent "Silence" notices posted throughout the building

There is history behind this place and worth the visit. Its is very creditable that it has been rebuilt and slowly getting back to its old glory. Lots of intellectuals have gone through this place and have benefited. It was nice to look around though not allowed to go inside.
This Library has been restored to its early glory, and contains a vast collection of valuable books.   It also acts as a centre of learning for the local students.  restricted acces to visitors.
It is a nice building, not really special. For me the most interesting was to see how proud they are about this building and how they use it. People are reading newspapers, there are archives, etc..

Architecturally a significant building with lovely laid out gardens. If you are visiting this place do yourselves a favour and avoid the frustration of being turned away from seeing anything but the corridors inside the building! Visiting Hours are limited to a couple in the evenings. It is clear that the staff here see visitors as an annoyance, they will not answer any questions and will simply walk away. There are signs everywhere that say 'Visitors Not allowed'. Best to take a couple of photos from the outside and move on.
The exterior looks a lot better than the interior. There is really nothing to see here. It is a good place walk around after visiting the fort. But definitely not a can't-miss attraction.
We have been told by the hotel owner to go there and we did. More than the building itself, it is observing the Which is pretty interesting!

As tourists/visitors are not permitted to enter you only to see the library sections from the desk at the entrance. There are som interesting photos from the days of the blast of the place. Do take a stroll around the buildning to enjoy the architecture and the garden. Have a snack/ drink/ meal from the library restaurant before leaving
it's sad during d war many rare books treasures etc were burnt n distroyed. Also it's was damaged  now re buit it again.

This was one of the biggest disappointments, as its such a hyped-up place. The visiting hours are restricted (between 4:30-6pm and you can only visit 2 small reading room areas - and everything else is closed to visitors! You might as well keep your shoes on (yes, its a library where you have to take off your shoes!!!) and look at the building from outside and save yourself the bother of going in. Not worth it at all.

I must have had a persuasive driver because I am unmistakenly a (white!) foreigner but was allowed in the library in the morning. I was able to have a good look round including a close look at the impressive array of books in the English section. There is also an Indian section recognising the close affinity between Jaffna and Southern India. The building is beautifully restored after the civil war. There were few people in the library but there was total silence and an air of learning just like I remember from English libraries in my boyhood. Nostalgia for a bygone age, a feeling of reconciliation after a bitter civil war and a building restored to its former glory all combine to make this a noteworthy place to visit and a welcome change (for me) from temple after temple. It's a great asset for local people and I could happily have browsed for half a day. It was my favourite place in Jaffna. I was privileged to have a chance to see it as a working library and it will always be difficult for the authorities to balance this with an opportunity for tourists to visit.

The Jaffna Public Library is a tourist destination when visiting the city.  Unfortunately, it is only open after 4:00pm for foreign visitors.  Therefore, you should plan accordingly if you choose to visit.  The grounds are spectacular with an assortment of flowers adorning them.  This building was rebuilt after it was damaged during the war.
The building is nice and the grounds are pretty. Only locals are able to access the collections in the library though so don't expect to actually be able to read anything.
I spent a bit of time here in the afternoon and it's a great place to get away from the hustle and bustle of central Jaffna

There are visiting times from 4-6. Very close to the town- in the town itself I would say, jaffna fort, library, nallur kovil, rio ice cream all are nearby. Unfortunately they dont allow you yo walk inside the library very much! But you can read some history and get a glimpse of the inside of the building. You can spend about 30 minutes here overall.

Visitors only allowed between 4:30 pm and 6 pm and the not actually allowed into any sections to see any books. Hardly public library more like a private members only. Gardens were nice but I would not waste my time

I did not entered the library, but it is a beautiful and big building between the fort and the city center. Start your visit of the city by the markets and the kovils of the city center, than go by foot to the fort (the library is in the way) to the sunset!!
The newest station  having also the newest tracks as recently reopened after the civil war gives you a good welcome and there is no hussle with tuktuks or taxis
Closed on public holidays and Poya days. You'll find the clock tower in front of the the library and the dutch fort is also few meters away from the library.
good. it is opens only for few hrs. so we missed. bad luck. for us okay. but better to open it at least for foreigners for the whole day
Very impressive little colonial building that was devastated during the civil war and is now renovated and back in use.

One of the best kept libraries in this country. A one time "best library" of the Asian region. Well that's history. Its prim and kept in a check. One needs to remove his/her shoes to enter. That's a mark of respect and to avoid disturbance. Most of the reading areas are not accessible to visitors, and permits only members. Kind of disappointing for an avid reader though, thus the visit was a shirt spin around for exterior selfies and angle shoots. Its only a landmark for a visitor.

The Public Library was burned down in June 1981 and is viewed as in of the defining moment of the Sri Lankan civil war.   More than 90,000 books, documents and ancient palm leaf books were destroyed.  It was viewed as aimed at the Tamil culture. The building has been rebuilt and is beautiful.  Unfortunately, it wasn't open when we visited.  It opens in the evenings only.
Before it was burned in the early 80's, Jaffna Library was a treasure of Tamil culture and knowledge. The modern reconstruction is a reminder of this former glory.

Jaffna Public Library , Sri Lanka One of Jaffna's most notable landmarks, it is run by the Jaffna Municipal Council. The library was built in 1933 and burnt in 1981. During the early 1980s, it was one of the biggest libraries in Asia, containing over 97,000 books and manuscripts.In 2001, rehabilitation of the library was completed, with new structure being built and new books received, although its old books and manuscripts were not replaced. It is Sri Lanka's second main public Library only rivaled by the Library in Colombo The building's classical lines and beautiful proportions make it stand out architecturally. It contains lush gardens and has been modernized with new facilities such as free-wifi

Visitors time is 4.30-6.30pm, But if you are solo or couple you should be able to visit the reading section and get permission to visit other areas. Please maintain silence and observe the rules. Good selection of books. Nice system. Definitely a place to see a good collection back again

The library was built in 1933 and burnt in 1981. But now it's almost renovated and only picture and posters remains. I would say there is nothing much to see now. It will be only opens at 4.30pm to 6pm only

A place filled with memories. Once known to be the largest library on the country and later burnt down by the terrorists with a lot of books to be found only in the Jaffna library. Rebuilt and back on its glory..

The exteriors of this building has been beautifully restored. Inside, you can see some old pictures of how the building looked like before it was damaged before the start of the civil war. It's also interesting to see locals inside the library reading books and newspapers. It's a good place to visit for half an hour.

Completele gutted in 1981, it's valuable collection of books and manuscripts redused to cinders, this beautiful building has been restored and lovingly refilled with books in the years following the war. The surrounding gardens are weel-kept and beautiful. It's a quiet oasis for book-lovers, and garden-lovers alike.

The Jaffna library has been restored to its original architecture after the war.  It is very well looked after with great gardens and excellent view of Jaffna. You are allowed to go inside the library but required to leave your foot wear outside.  The place a great importance of learning so their way of showing respect is to walk without foot wear.  From a practical perspective this reduces the noise levels and the need for regular cleaning of the library.

First of all the gardens seem like a little slice of Eden in the heat of a Jaffna mid morning. Managed to get in before the actual visiting hours which are from 4-6pm. Nice to see that the library has strict rules and study and reading are the first priority. Have to take your shoes off to enter the building. There's a fascinating mix of literature within its walls with most books quite old and providing interesting view points on their subjects. There is a reference room but requires membership to enter. Lovely grounds to stroll through and definitely would recommend a visit while you're in Jaffna

The library only opens after 4:30pm, so please don't go if you want to go inside to have a look. It is close either 6pm or 6:30pm.. can't remember .. It is quite a shame that most sections are not open for visitors. Everyone have to remove their shoes before entering. It is interesting to see that they seperate male and female reading rooms. Male is downstairs and female one is upstairs. No photograph is allow inside, and so can't share any photos.
Wow.. some priceless books also in this library.. and nice place..  This library gave me a good feeling. One of the best library in sri Lanka this is. nothing else to say  anything...

The library is only open to visitors from 4.30pm to 6.00pm for free each day except public holidays and then you are only permitted to enter the reading room on the ground floor. There is not a lot to see other than a couple of photographs at the library entrance showing the damage after the library contents were burned in 1981, one of the incidents to spark the civil war. However it is a very impressive building with lovely landscaped gardens surrounding it.

The Library is very big. However nothing much for a visitor to see as only a small section is open to public. Understand that public visiting the reading areas would disturb the users however maybe tours should be arranged with a guide when library is closed.

The Jaffna Public Library is advertised as one of the sights to see in Northern Sri Lanka, During the civil war the Library which was even then one of the hallmarks of Jaffna was burnt down and now rebuilt. I had sent some books to Jaffna for the library, so I looked forward to seeing it. I went on a Sunday morning and was told it was closed, so I made an arrangement,  after a conversation with the man at the gate, to come in early the next morning. I arrived at 9am and was told that visitors were allowed only after 4pm. I explained to the only one who could speak in English that I was from Australia, and that I had an interest in seeing the complex. I still had the same reply. In the end they let me through but showed no interest in my appearance there. I did not see all of it to make any comment. I felt that I was being treated as a inconvenience to be tolerated, and so I left. If you advertise something as a tourist attraction the you should make arrangements to make sure your visitors are made welcome. I do not think I will go back there and while I wish them success I will not personally contribute.
It didn't opened when I went there. Seems it would be open between 4-7 or so, but not in the noon. Worth a visit.
One of the oldest libraries in south east Asia now renovated after an unfortunate incident during the insurrection.
Lovley library but few areas off limits for foreigners  lovley building n gardens  not far from town and fort

Nothing much to see. you can wander inside the building. But you have to take off your shoes before you enter it. But most of the areas of the building are prohibited to the travelers. It is understandable because it is a library.
Well worth a visit in the late afternoon to wander through the rooms and end up on the balcony overlooking the gardens.

Beautiful building restored after its destruction by racist forces, incredibly important both historically and symbolically. You cannot take photos inside because it is still a functioning library, but you can peek.

Having Sri Lankan parents, they raved about  the library for a long time and were proud for what it stood for. But visiting for the first time as a 'foreigner' there are signs telling you that the books area is forbidden. This is absurd. In no other country are you told to not read a book in a library. They told us that certain visitors come and destroy the books but that's why there are employees and security personnel. Waste of time which is upsetting as this is my heritage

Jaffna Public Library is supposed to be the biggest in whole Sri Lanka. There are many different sections - some of them are prohibited for tourists, but one friendly librarian showed me them anyway. Recommend it if you are strongly interested in books and reading, otherwise it won't be interesting to you. From the balcony you can see the Cricket Stadium and Jaffna Fort. The library is also opened for visitors every day from 4.30 p.m. until 6 p.m., so please not go there in the morning.

Opening hours are from 4-6pm only. We were there in the morning and had other plans for the afternoon, thus missed visiting it. The Public Library has some of the oldest manuscripts and documents of the region and of the Tamil language, so we were disappointed to have missed going in.

We visited there in the morning which we didn't have any clue that the visiting hours are in the evening. The security wasn't friendly and had a rude tone telling us that we should visit in the evening. Inside the library looks like any other library. The architecture from the outside is nice to watch.

Socrates said that the first victim of the war is truth, and it is equally true that places of learning and art also suffer greatly in war as a deliberate attempt to  damage the collective memory This was once one of the greatest  libraries in Asia, containing  97,000 books and manuscripts and much of it was burnt in the civil conflict. It has  now been painstakingly restored, and once again looks beautiful but the loss of burnt books cannot never be compensated.

We were only able to go into the main hall, where the periodicals are kept. It was like entering another time zone - the furnishings, the building - the entire ambiance.  Definitely a site to visit.  The grounds are spectacular.
i lucked out arriving the day and time that the library was putting on a play, also i explored the building. very nice place and worth visiting.
This is a very famous and great Library in Sri Lanka. Built in ancient time. It was burnt during the war in 1981. Now it is completely recovered. There are nearly 100,000 books.
This library is the most peaceful with a large array of books and a wonderful view of the sea on the second floor. Extremely peaceful for people who want to unwind.
We were very disappointed with the interior. It was not set up for visitors and most rooms leading from the corridors were out of bounds for tourists

The building itself is nice and history behind it very heavy, but besides taking a picture of the building there is not much to see there. Access is limited to members only. Why not if you have extra time, it's next the fort entrance.
The was destroyed years back and now fully  renovated. This has a very large collection. Visitors are allowed to go in after 4 pm and restricted to a selected area
See above. Building is great, just cannot get anywhere inside which was disappointing. If they could open a couple of sections, as I would have really liked to have seen some of the older books etc.
Jaffna Library was burnt down during the civil war and recently fully renovated. It is a must visit site for travellers going to jaffna
Great location near the fort and interesting for what it is hoping to replace: the building itself as well as the collection. What a pity the original had gone.
Once a legend that was smashed down by piety politics but glade it stands again as we have heard in past. it will serve our nation more than before

The visit to the library was a excellent trip.The library looks attractive after the renovation some years back.This library is world famous with a large collection of books.Very famous persons visited the library in Jaffna.The location is maintained properly.

No visit to Jaffna would be complete without a visit to the well known Public Library, seeped in history and .... misfortune. The building, together with its valuable collection, was destroyed twice but now the Library stands tall, a beacon of knowledge in the north of Sri Lanka. Among the special sections are : the Sri Lanka collection and a room dedicated to Indian publications. The children's section is bright and colourful with a lot of activity on the Saturday morning that we visited. Visitors are required to remove their shoes before entering the Library.
If you are hoping to see the excellent book collection, please become a member. You can get a temporary membership at the counter. Otherwise, all you can do is admire the building and its gardens.
This place is very popular with locals. This is a historical place in jaffna. A lot of books are here. And rare once also. Nice architecture of building.
This Library is one of the Best In Asia. This has variety of rare books. Very popular with the public. This an Icon in Jaffna.

Given the historical significance of this place it is worth visiting. Don't miss the photos of the damage from 1981 above the doorways in the reception area. But it is, more than anything else, a working library and a visit doesn't take more than 15 mins. At the moment there is a little exhibition outside on 60 years of Sri Lanka in the UN.

We were allowed to walk around the grounds of the library, but were not allowed to enter the building, as visiting hours were late afternoon only. There was a very interesting exhibition outside,  on the work of the United Nations in Sri Lanka.

First of all its open to visitors only between 4:30-6! It's a nice place to see but I was expecting a whole lot more space/ rooms with books.... But there are some things you can see and even learn.... The structure is magnificent!!

This is a must see see place in Jaffna as it is one of the key sites that jaffna is known for. There are very specific visiting hours from 4.30pm to 7pm. Most of the library halls are closed to visitors, but you can take a quick peep through the doors.

Gleaming white under the Sri Lanka sun, the building's classical lines or colonial style stands proud in the Northern City of Jaffna.  The building itself has beautiful proportions and make it one of the architectural standouts of the South Asia region.  What is not appreciated is that during the Civil War this building was reduced to ashes so many times.  A war torn region this building represents the Phoenix Like rebuilding of a war torn area.  Originally this library had one of the most eclectic collections of books ranging to about 97,000 books and articles pertaining to the Tamil Life and History. All sadly destroyed. Now things are returning to normal - what ever normal can be in this day and age.  Worth a visit but I would allow no longer than 1 hour if that to wander round the existing building.

Looks quite an impressive building but the day we visited it was closed ,so we went to the cafe for afternoon tea & cake it was fairly full as folks where taking there driving tests in a field opposite driving round traffic cones!!!!!!!!!!does that explain the erratic driving  me thinks,they all seemed pleased they passed came to celebrate over a soda.

Building is kept clean and well maintained. Its a Historic Place. Having had a bad experience 3 decades ago, now the place has come back to its origin. Well done. Staff good. Unwanted elements are not found. Visitors enjoy their visit. Its worth it.

Though the collection is less (it was burnt down in 1980s), the renovated library (with foreign foundations) has excellent architecture, good furniture, excellent children's wing, Computer wing and a good park outside to relax. Portiobs are air conditioned. An excellent place to visit
Beautiful building from outside, nice garden,easy to find, visitors are not allowed to go the "sections"...so basically you can walk only in corridors...but will not take you more than 15 minutes.

One time graded as the best in South Asia but lost almost all the manuscripts and invaluable collection of books. Visiting time is 4.30 pm so those who would like to go there, please arrange your schedule according to this. Good to see the well maintained garden as Jaffna is a challenging place for this kind of green.
Libraries are always nice place to have a break from the city life and get quiet and learn some more.
The library is open for public viewing only from 4.30 pm to 6 pm. You can walk through a few public areas on the ground floor and the first floor.

Although the building is quite nice, do realize this has been completely rebuilt after the civil war, so it's historic value is a bit less than meets the eye... You can skip going inside if you're in a hurry as the inside offers a standard public library with entry to the sections prohibited for visitors. You are able to see some pictures of the building before the restoration inside if it interests you

Visitors can visit daily from 4.30 - 6 pm but if you did happen to miss these times, don't feel that you've missed out, It's just a huge building but hardly anything to see inside. Didn't see one book!
Very sadly there is little inside as all the treasures were burned by arsonists. The architecture of building must be seen. No need to spend too much time here
It's one of the best libraries at south asia. You need to remove shoes before entering to the library.
Nice place to visit but unfortunately we picked a day when it was not open to tourists so only got a quick peak round the outside. Next trip will plan better to take a look on the inside!

There is not much left from the Original building. After the war the library is rebuilt but lots of old Tamil documents are damaged or burnt. In the building itself it is prohibited to make pictures and the sections are not open for public. You can climb the stairs to 1st floor to enjoy the view. The corridors on the ground floor are free to visit and so you can glimpse a little in the sections. That is about all. So, from the outside it is a beautiful piece of architecture but from the inside it is rather disappointing.

Even after it was burnt down by the time of conflict  , today Jaffna public library stands still after renovations,this building it self resembles the perseverance and strength of city's people,by standing tall in the middle of Jaffna city. .Library is not open to tourists  on Mondays, other days except week ends it's opened to tourists after 4.00 PM, Once in side the library you are given limited access to the library, as a visitor you are not able to see all the rooms with books or sit and read a book, you are only given a chance just to see the reception area, a hall way leading to a computer room. However the library is one of the must see places in Jaffna as it is a historic building.

This library was destroyed during the war and now its rebuild to reflect the past glory. We couldn't visit inside the library as we arrived at a time where it was closed. But we enjoyed looking at the building.

The rebuilt library is certainly an impressive building. No photos are allowed inside and many of the rooms are not accessible to visitors. The periodicals room is very good though with lots of english language things to read.

The history if this library is fascinating and that alone is worth a visit.This is where it all started in terms of Sri Lankan civil war in force. Tamil heritage manuscripts *palm leaves) and about 91,000 volume of books involving Tamil history was burnt to ground by mob (with the blessing from official government) in the early 80's. After the war ended about 6 years ago, Janna people built the library first. It is an amazing testament to the Tamil's intellectual and will power.The building from outside is pretty to look at. The only problem is tourists can not get access to anywhere but the reading room. There are photos of NY Public Library, Library of Congress and Columbia University's library which is my husband's alma mater and my husband is a retired professor/founder of the Dental School in Stoney Brook in NY. I asked him to go to the front desk, introduce himself and ask if we can go inside to see the collection. It was very easily granted. What was disconcerting is how they are now storing the donated palm leaf manuscripts. They were very kind to open the cabinet and let us touch (we did NOT) but we were horrified to see that these manuscripts are not even properly folded. They are just piled up, dis organized, collecting dust. Rest of the rooms have some Tamil and some English books and no, it is not a world class collection. However, how does one tiny city in a tiny country rebuild a world class library after losing 91,000 volumes of its heritage? I almost wept in emotion.

Thia is a amazing Library, one must visit when in Jaffna and the pathetic story was during 1980's this place was set fire due to an ethnic issue in the country and there was very unfounded books were burnt. Well maintain Library in Sri Lanka and pretty nice location in Jaffna
it's a huge building in Jaffna with a bit of a history. It was worth a photo. I wouldn't plan too much time here.

The Jaffna library has come a long way. it was set on fire in 1983 because of ethnic tensions and most of its valuable and historic Tamil scriptures were destroyed but it has been rebuilt and its modernization is impressive. There was a hidden art gallery on one of the floors which is worth finding.
Was a good place to visit but access to most of the places are restricted apart from the reading rooms.

Not much to see on the inside. With visitor hours being 16:30 - 18:00, if you can't make it inside during those hours, you're not missing too much. Just about every corridor is closed for visitors. But, since it's free I can't complain too much!

Beautiful architecture but recently restored due to bombing in the civil war. Historical photos available for public viewing showing how it was and when it was bombed. If you go upstairs make sure you go out onto the balcony at the front. There is a lovely view overlooking the gardens. Well worth the adventure.
An amazing symbolic structure that amazes you with its outside an inner beauty. And both the old and new story of it is a vital part of understanding the history.

This is one of the most popular place in the Northern province of Sri Lanka - Jaffna. This library was the one of the biggest in early 80s in Asia and then burnt in 1983. This is one of the symbol of the conflict affected people. Though the building is renovated and reopened for public, the people still carry their inner wounds as unhealed.
This was a nostalgic trip for us and revisiting places that our grandparents frequented was a wonderful experience. The staff were very understanding and accomodating. Highly recommend a visit
Historic building, bring sadness to anyone getting to this library was burnt once with so many Historic books. Let history not repeat itself

It was good to see this famous building brought back to its old glory. Was able to do a tour inside. The library is well equipped & modern now. It was nice going up to see the view of the surrounding area, from the balcony. The downside of the place is a dirty canal that is at the entrance to the library, which  has not been cleaned up  for ages, as foreign tourists  & children visit the library, the canal  should be cleaned up soon,  it is a health hazard &  very ugly as it is at the entrance.

A lovely, proud building with an important story behind it. As with so much in Jaffna (apart from the busy market), it is quiet and unassuming and worth visiting, even if for just a cursory stroll. An important symbol of Tamil identity, read up on its history; it will make the visit even better. A good reading room as well.
A modern building built on the ruins of the previous Library which was burnt down with all the ancient manuscripts. To see but i would not recommend a visit, it's a library.
I attended a forum here. The facilities were modern, the sound system was up to date, the room was air-conditioned - a nice venue for business and education.
they day we went they said it was not open to foreingeners ? till 4pm but we never had enuff time to go back ., great looking building tho ..good luck getting in

Jaffna Public Library is one of the main attraction of Jaffna located in the Jaffna City Centre itself, along Jaffna Dutch Fort and British Clock Tower. This is the second largest library in south Asia which was built 8 decades ago back in 1933. The locatian in the city center allowes any visitor to view the beauty of the unique architecture of the libray and the valuable contents. Although, a remarkable amount of books were lost during the confict lasted for more than 03 decades, the renovated building and collection of books gives a new look for the library now. The library is closed for public on Monday and there is no entrence fee. More information about Jaffna Public Library can be seen at www.jaffnalibrary.lk.

Well tended garden, imposing building and a restored library after all its literary resources were destroyed in a fire. The library has many books and has a vast assortment of readers and borrowers of many ages. One thing I noticed though was that, even though the staff is greatly dedicated, there not many qualified librarians here.  The indexing, classification of books and arrangement according to genre, author, was in wanting. Some help from  visitors who can assist  the Library Management in this area can be helpful.
This public Library is one of the famous one and had a lots of Books.This was burnt down during the unrest and later restructured with the same old style.
Worth popping into see after or before going to Jaffna Fort - if only to see the extent of the post war restoration work. Peaceful and cool.

It had become an attraction for tourists only due to its past destruction during the conflict. Even I went to see the place to see it's majesty look and books it is enriched with. But disappointment as tourists are not allowed to go through the books Available in the library, even after buying a ticket to enter the library as a tourist. You could go and have a look at some pictures taken after the destruction and information about few missing journalists during the conflict. It will be a definite disappointment to tourists who are really eager to know about the books it has. But for a tourist looking for a architectural beauty of a building, got something to enjoy.

This beautiful, huge public library was burnt down at one stage during the civil war. I was unable to visit inside but its exterior looks most impressive. It is a grand, working monument to peoples' education.

Before destroyed by the LTTE this was the biggest libraries in south east asia, and now have reconstructed with the same architectural structure. Opened for public from 4pm to 6pm only. Not much to see inside other than a normal library. Important because of the historical value
Famous Jaffna library. Fine old building and access for tge public to the library. Nothing much else to note.

The library is nice to visit. You can have a quick look around but will have seen it in an hour. For us it was just nice to escape from the heat for a little while. The best think about it is the outside as it is a nice building.

Impressive that despite decades of war, the people in the region prize learning, education, and preserving books. Although it was burnt down during the war, a lot of effort went into getting this place up and running again. Happy to see so many students using the library and checking out books.
Cant say I loved it - but the story is quite interesting. Would step by for a few minutes as part of bigger Jaffna tour
It was the biggest library in the Continent. During the conflict it was destroyed and it was a base for fight. Everybody has to contribute in the form of books to make it glory again
Could only see from outside as visiting times are limited.  What we heard about makes it worth trying to get inside.
This library was completely burned down by the LTTE during the war. A lot was lot in that fire and now it has been rebuilt. Open to the public: 4pm-6pm Entrance fee: Rs. 10/=

The biggest library in Asia (at early 1980) which was burnt due to the conflict. The oldest building was renovated and handed over to the public recently. This library is located near to the general bus stand, closed to the Fort (dutch) and used by almost all the armed groups as a  base for their fight during the conflict time.

In  any part of SriLanka library is not a tourist attraction other than Jaffna. This has a history This library was one of the best in Asia if not in the world. People of this area treat this as a place of worship (Temple, Church or Mosque). When this was burnt down every body cried and condemned. This is a new construction with new books but the old books and leaf records were destroyed . Still all Sri Lankans contributed in some way to redo the library. because of this back round this is visited by all visitors to Jaffna. This is the only place I have seen the visitors are not permitted with their footwear, there is a place to keep  your foot wear. There is no entry  fee but certain time restrictions are there I guess it is after 4 pm better you check before you go there. Apart from this this is a library.

One of the sites to take in, when in Jaffna. Has been restored, the bright white building stands out on the sky line near the seaside. The library gardens are on quite a large block, and it is surrounded by parks and fields, and lake, so it is good to take a peaceful walk around, just outside the city centre. Bring a bit of food for the resident dog (he's shown on dog-star charity). Their health could certainly use it to stave off the mites. The children's park is just across the road, and the courts building a further block away. It is also easy to visit the library, and then walk a short distance, past the pillar, stadium, and around to the old fort. A good walk with sea breeze.
